Protocols/STPShippingAddressViewControll.name: -shippingAddressViewControllerDidCancel:
Protocols/STPShippingAddressViewControll.abstract: Called when the user cancels entering a shipping address. You should dismiss (or pop) the view controller at this point.

Protocols/STPShippingAddressViewControll.name: -shippingAddressViewController:didEnterAddress:completion:
Protocols/STPShippingAddressViewControll.abstract: This is called when the user enters a shipping address and taps next. You should validate the address and determine what shipping methods are available, and call the completion block when finished. If an error occurrs, call the completion block with the error. Otherwise, call the completion block with a nil error and an array of available shipping methods. If you don’t need to collect a shipping method, you may pass an empty array.

Protocols/STPShippingAddressViewControll.name: -shippingAddressViewController:didFinishWithAddress:shippingMethod:
Protocols/STPShippingAddressViewControll.abstract: This is called when the user selects a shipping method. If no shipping methods are given, or if the shipping type doesn’t require a shipping method, this will be called after the user has a shipping address and your validation has succeeded. After updating your app with the user’s shipping info, you should dismiss (or pop) the view controller. Note that if shippingMethod is non-nil, there will be an additional shipping methods view controller on the navigation controller’s stack.

Protocols/STPPaymentMethodsViewControlle.name: -paymentMethodsViewController:didFailToLoadWithError:
Protocols/STPPaymentMethodsViewControlle.abstract: This is called when the view controller encounters an error fetching the user’s payment methods from its API adapter. You should dismiss the view controller when this is called.

Protocols/STPPaymentMethodsViewControlle.name: -paymentMethodsViewControllerDidFinish:
Protocols/STPPaymentMethodsViewControlle.abstract: This is called when the user selects or adds a payment method, so it will often be called immediately after calling paymentMethodsViewController:didSelectPaymentMethod:. You should dismiss the view controller when this is called.

Protocols/STPPaymentMethodsViewControlle.name: -paymentMethodsViewControllerDidCancel:
Protocols/STPPaymentMethodsViewControlle.abstract: This is called when the user taps cancel.

Protocols/STPPaymentMethodsViewControlle.name: -paymentMethodsViewController:didSelectPaymentMethod:
Protocols/STPPaymentMethodsViewControlle.abstract: This is called when the user either makes a selection, or adds a new card. This will be triggered after the view controller loads with the user’s current selection (if they have one) and then subsequently when they change their choice. You should use this callback to update any necessary UI in your app that displays the user’s currently selected payment method. You should not dismiss the view controller at this point, instead do this in paymentMethodsViewControllerDidFinish:. STPPaymentMethodsViewController will also call the necessary methods on your API adapter, so you don’t need to call them directly during this method.

Protocols/STPPaymentMethod.html#/c:objc(.name: image
Protocols/STPPaymentMethod.html#/c:objc(.abstract: A small (32 x 20 points) logo image representing the payment method. For example, the Visa logo for a Visa card, or the Apple Pay logo.

Protocols/STPPaymentMethod.html#/c:objc(.name: templateImage
Protocols/STPPaymentMethod.html#/c:objc(.abstract: A small (32 x 20 points) logo image representing the payment method that can be used as template for tinted icons.

Protocols/STPPaymentMethod.html#/c:objc(.name: label
Protocols/STPPaymentMethod.html#/c:objc(.abstract: A string describing the payment method, such as Apple Pay or Visa 4242.

Protocols/STPPaymentContextDelegate.html.name: -paymentContextDidChange:
Protocols/STPPaymentContextDelegate.html.abstract: This is called every time the contents of the payment context change. When this is called, you should update your app’s UI to reflect the current state of the payment context. For example, if you have a checkout page with a selected payment method row, you should update its payment method with paymentContext.selectedPaymentMethod.label. If that checkout page has a buy button, you should enable/disable it depending on the result of [paymentContext isReadyForPayment].

Protocols/STPPaymentContextDelegate.html.name: -paymentContext:didCreatePaymentResult:completion:
Protocols/STPPaymentContextDelegate.html.abstract: Inside this method, you should make a call to your backend API to make a charge with that Customer + source, and invoke the completion block when that is done.

Protocols/STPPaymentContextDelegate.html.name: -paymentContext:didFinishWithStatus:error:
Protocols/STPPaymentContextDelegate.html.abstract: This is invoked by an STPPaymentContext when it is finished. This will be called after the payment is done and all necessary UI has been dismissed. You should inspect the returned status and behave appropriately. For example: if it’s STPPaymentStatusSuccess, show the user a receipt. If it’s STPPaymentStatusError, inform the user of the error. If it’s STPPaymentStatusUserCanceled, do nothing.

Protocols/STPPaymentContextDelegate.html.name: -paymentContext:didUpdateShippingAddress:completion:
Protocols/STPPaymentContextDelegate.html.abstract: Inside this method, you should verify that you can ship to the given address.

Protocols/STPPaymentCardTextFieldDelegat.name: -paymentCardTextFieldDidBeginEditingNumber:
Protocols/STPPaymentCardTextFieldDelegat.abstract: Called when editing begins in the payment card field’s number field.

Protocols/STPPaymentCardTextFieldDelegat.name: -paymentCardTextFieldDidEndEditingNumber:
Protocols/STPPaymentCardTextFieldDelegat.abstract: Called when editing ends in the payment card field’s number field.

Protocols/STPPaymentCardTextFieldDelegat.name: -paymentCardTextFieldDidBeginEditingCVC:
Protocols/STPPaymentCardTextFieldDelegat.abstract: Called when editing begins in the payment card field’s CVC field.

Protocols/STPPaymentCardTextFieldDelegat.name: -paymentCardTextFieldDidEndEditingCVC:
Protocols/STPPaymentCardTextFieldDelegat.abstract: Called when editing ends in the payment card field’s CVC field.

Protocols/STPPaymentCardTextFieldDelegat.name: -paymentCardTextFieldDidBeginEditingExpiration:
Protocols/STPPaymentCardTextFieldDelegat.abstract: Called when editing begins in the payment card field’s expiration field.

Protocols/STPPaymentCardTextFieldDelegat.name: -paymentCardTextFieldDidEndEditingExpiration:
Protocols/STPPaymentCardTextFieldDelegat.abstract: Called when editing ends in the payment card field’s expiration field.

Protocols/STPFormEncodable.html#/c:objc(.name: +rootObjectName
Protocols/STPFormEncodable.html#/c:objc(.abstract: The root object name to be used when converting this object to a form-encoded string. For example, if this returns @card, then the form-encoded output will resemble @card[foo]=bar (where ‘foo’ and ‘bar’ are specified by propertyNamesToFormFieldNamesMapping below.

Protocols/STPFormEncodable.html#/c:objc(.name: +propertyNamesToFormFieldNamesMapping
Protocols/STPFormEncodable.html#/c:objc(.abstract: This maps properties on an object that is being form-encoded into parameter names in the Stripe API. For example, STPCardParams has a field called expMonth, but the Stripe API expects a field called exp_month. This dictionary represents a mapping from the former to the latter (in other words, [STPCardParams propertyNamesToFormFieldNamesMapping][@expMonth] == @exp_month.)

Protocols/STPFormEncodable.html#/c:objc(.name: additionalAPIParameters
Protocols/STPFormEncodable.html#/c:objc(.abstract: You can use this property to add additional fields to an API request that are not explicitly defined by the object’s interface. This can be useful when using beta features that haven’t been added to the Stripe SDK yet. For example, if the /v1/tokens API began to accept a beta field called test_field, you might do the following:

Protocols/STPEphemeralKeyProvider.html#/.name: -createCustomerKeyWithAPIVersion:completion:
Protocols/STPEphemeralKeyProvider.html#/.abstract: Creates a new ephemeral key for retrieving and updating a Stripe customer.

Protocols/STPBackendAPIAdapter.html#/c:o.name: -retrieveCustomer:
Protocols/STPBackendAPIAdapter.html#/c:o.abstract: Retrieve the cards to be displayed inside a payment context. On your backend, retrieve the Stripe customer associated with your currently logged-in user (see https://stripe.com/docs/api#retrieve_customer ), and return the raw JSON response from the Stripe API. (For an example Ruby implementation of this API, see https://github.com/stripe/example-ios-backend/blob/master/web.rb#L40 ). Back in your iOS app, after you’ve called this API, deserialize your API response into an STPCustomer object (you can use the STPCustomerDeserializer class to do this). See MyAPIClient.swift in our example project to see this in action.

Protocols/STPBackendAPIAdapter.html#/c:o.name: -attachSourceToCustomer:completion:
Protocols/STPBackendAPIAdapter.html#/c:o.abstract: Adds a payment source to a customer. On your backend, retrieve the Stripe customer associated with your logged-in user. Then, call the Update Customer method on that customer as described at https://stripe.com/docs/api#update_customer (for an example Ruby implementation of this API, see https://github.com/stripe/example-ios-backend/blob/master/web.rb#L60 ). If this API call succeeds, call completion(nil). Otherwise, call completion(error) with the error that occurred.

Protocols/STPBackendAPIAdapter.html#/c:o.name: -selectDefaultCustomerSource:completion:
Protocols/STPBackendAPIAdapter.html#/c:o.abstract: Change a customer’s default_source to be the provided card. On your backend, retrieve the Stripe customer associated with your logged-in user. Then, call the Customer Update method as described at https://stripe.com/docs/api#update_customer , specifying default_source to be the value of source.stripeID (for an example Ruby implementation of this API, see https://github.com/stripe/example-ios-backend/blob/master/web.rb#L82 ). If this API call succeeds, call completion(nil). Otherwise, call completion(error) with the error that occurred.

Protocols/STPAddCardViewControllerDelega.name: -addCardViewControllerDidCancel:
Protocols/STPAddCardViewControllerDelega.abstract: Called when the user cancels adding a card. You should dismiss (or pop) the view controller at this point.

Protocols/STPAddCardViewControllerDelega.name: -addCardViewController:didCreateToken:completion:
Protocols/STPAddCardViewControllerDelega.abstract: This is called when the user successfully adds a card and tokenizes it with Stripe. You should send the token to your backend to store it on a customer, and then call the provided completion block when that call is finished. If an error occurred while talking to your backend, call completion(error), otherwise, dismiss (or pop) the view controller.

Protocols/STPAddCardViewControllerDelega.name: STPAddCardViewControllerDelegate
Protocols/STPAddCardViewControllerDelega.abstract: An STPAddCardViewControllerDelegate is notified when an STPAddCardViewController successfully creates a card token or is cancelled. It has internal error-handling logic, so there’s no error case to deal with.

Protocols/STPBackendAPIAdapter.html.name: STPBackendAPIAdapter
Protocols/STPBackendAPIAdapter.html.abstract: You should make your application’s API client conform to this interface in order to use it with an STPPaymentContext. It provides a bridge from the prebuilt UI we expose (such as STPPaymentMethodsViewController) to your backend to fetch the information it needs to power those views. To read about how to implement this protocol, see https://stripe.com/docs/mobile/ios/standard#prepare-your-api . To see examples of implementing these APIs, see MyAPIClient.swift in our example project and https://github.com/stripe/example-ios-backend .

Protocols/STPEphemeralKeyProvider.html.name: STPEphemeralKeyProvider
Protocols/STPEphemeralKeyProvider.html.abstract: You should make your application’s API client conform to this interface.

Protocols/STPFormEncodable.html.name: STPFormEncodable
Protocols/STPFormEncodable.html.abstract: Objects conforming to STPFormEncodable can be automatically converted to a form-encoded string, which can then be used when making requests to the Stripe API.

Protocols/STPPaymentCardTextFieldDelegat.name: STPPaymentCardTextFieldDelegate
Protocols/STPPaymentCardTextFieldDelegat.abstract: This protocol allows a delegate to be notified when a payment text field’s contents change, which can in turn be used to take further actions depending on the validity of its contents.

Protocols/STPPaymentContextDelegate.html.name: STPPaymentContextDelegate
Protocols/STPPaymentContextDelegate.html.abstract: Implement STPPaymentContextDelegate to get notified when a payment context changes, finishes, encounters errors, etc. In practice, if your app has a checkout screen view controller, that is a good candidate to implement this protocol.

Protocols/STPPaymentMethod.html.name: STPPaymentMethod
Protocols/STPPaymentMethod.html.abstract: This protocol represents a payment method that a user can select and use to pay. Currently the only classes that conform to it are STPCard (which represents that the user wants to pay with a specific card) and STPApplePayPaymentMethod (which represents that the user wants to pay with Apple Pay).

Protocols/STPPaymentMethodsViewControlle.name: STPPaymentMethodsViewControllerDelegate
Protocols/STPPaymentMethodsViewControlle.abstract: An STPPaymentMethodsViewControllerDelegate responds when a user selects a payment method from (or cancels) an STPPaymentMethodsViewController. In both of these instances, you should dismiss the view controller (either by popping it off the navigation stack, or dismissing it).

Protocols/STPShippingAddressViewControll.name: STPShippingAddressViewControllerDelegate
Protocols/STPShippingAddressViewControll.abstract: An STPShippingAddressViewControllerDelegate is notified when an STPShippingAddressViewController receives an address, completes with an address, or is cancelled.

Protocols/STPSourceProtocol.html.name: STPSourceProtocol
Protocols/STPSourceProtocol.html.abstract: Objects conforming to this protocol can be attached to a Stripe Customer object as a payment source.

Enums.html#/c:@E@STPRedirectContextState.abstract: Possible states for the redirect context to be in

Classes/STPToken.html#/c:objc(cs)STPToke.abstract: The value of the token. You can store this value on your server and use it to make charges and customers.

Classes/STPToken.html#/c:objc(cs)STPToke.abstract: Whether or not this token was created in livemode. Will be YES if you used your Live Publishable Key, and NO if you used your Test Publishable Key.

Classes/STPToken.html#/c:objc(cs)STPToke.abstract: The credit card details that were used to create the token. Will only be set if the token was created via a credit card or Apple Pay, otherwise it will be

Classes/STPTheme.html#/c:objc(cs)STPThem.name: +defaultTheme
Classes/STPTheme.html#/c:objc(cs)STPThem.abstract: The default theme used by all Stripe UI. All themable UI classes, such as STPAddCardViewController, have one initializer that takes a theme and one that does not. If you use the one that does not, the default theme will be used to customize that view controller’s appearance.

Classes/STPTheme.html#/c:objc(cs)STPThem.name: primaryBackgroundColor
Classes/STPTheme.html#/c:objc(cs)STPThem.abstract: The primary background color of the theme. This will be used as the backgroundColor for any views with this theme.

Classes/STPTheme.html#/c:objc(cs)STPThem.name: secondaryBackgroundColor
Classes/STPTheme.html#/c:objc(cs)STPThem.abstract: The secondary background color of this theme. This will be used as the backgroundColor for any supplemental views inside a view with this theme - for example, a UITableView will set it’s cells’ background color to this value.

Classes/STPTheme.html#/c:objc(cs)STPThem.name: tertiaryBackgroundColor
Classes/STPTheme.html#/c:objc(cs)STPThem.abstract: This color is automatically derived by reducing the alpha of the primaryBackgroundColor and is used as a section border color in table view cells.

Classes/STPTheme.html#/c:objc(cs)STPThem.name: quaternaryBackgroundColor
Classes/STPTheme.html#/c:objc(cs)STPThem.abstract: This color is automatically derived by reducing the brightness of the primaryBackgroundColor and is used as a separator color in table view cells.

Classes/STPTheme.html#/c:objc(cs)STPThem.name: primaryForegroundColor
Classes/STPTheme.html#/c:objc(cs)STPThem.abstract: The primary foreground color of this theme. This will be used as the text color for any important labels in a view with this theme (such as the text color for a text field that the user needs to fill out).

Classes/STPTheme.html#/c:objc(cs)STPThem.name: secondaryForegroundColor
Classes/STPTheme.html#/c:objc(cs)STPThem.abstract: The secondary foreground color of this theme. This will be used as the text color for any supplementary labels in a view with this theme (such as the placeholder color for a text field that the user needs to fill out).

Classes/STPTheme.html#/c:objc(cs)STPThem.name: tertiaryForegroundColor
Classes/STPTheme.html#/c:objc(cs)STPThem.abstract: This color is automatically derived from the secondaryForegroundColor with a lower alpha component, used for disabled text.

Classes/STPTheme.html#/c:objc(cs)STPThem.name: accentColor
Classes/STPTheme.html#/c:objc(cs)STPThem.abstract: The accent color of this theme - it will be used for any buttons and other elements on a view that are important to highlight.

Classes/STPTheme.html#/c:objc(cs)STPThem.name: errorColor
Classes/STPTheme.html#/c:objc(cs)STPThem.abstract: The error color of this theme - it will be used for rendering any error messages or views.

Classes/STPTheme.html#/c:objc(cs)STPThem.name: font
Classes/STPTheme.html#/c:objc(cs)STPThem.abstract: The font to be used for all views using this theme. Make sure to select an appropriate size.

Classes/STPTheme.html#/c:objc(cs)STPThem.name: emphasisFont
Classes/STPTheme.html#/c:objc(cs)STPThem.abstract: The medium-weight font to be used for all bold text in views using this theme. Make sure to select an appropriate size.

Classes/STPTheme.html#/c:objc(cs)STPThem.name: barStyle
Classes/STPTheme.html#/c:objc(cs)STPThem.abstract: The navigation bar style to use for any view controllers presented modally

Classes/STPTheme.html#/c:objc(cs)STPThem.name: translucentNavigationBar
Classes/STPTheme.html#/c:objc(cs)STPThem.abstract: A Boolean value indicating whether the navigation bar for any view controllers

Classes/STPTheme.html#/c:objc(cs)STPThem.name: smallFont
Classes/STPTheme.html#/c:objc(cs)STPThem.abstract: This font is automatically derived from the font, with a slightly lower point size, and will be used for supplementary labels.

Classes/STPTheme.html#/c:objc(cs)STPThem.name: largeFont
Classes/STPTheme.html#/c:objc(cs)STPThem.abstract: This font is automatically derived from the font, with a larger point size, and will be used for large labels such as SMS code entry.

Classes/STPSourceRedirect.html#/c:objc(c.name: url

Classes/STPSourceReceiver.html#/c:objc(c.abstract: The address of the receiver source. This is the value that should be communicated to the customer to send their funds to.

Classes/STPSourceReceiver.html#/c:objc(c.name: amountReceived

Classes/STPSourceReceiver.html#/c:objc(c.name: amountReturned
Classes/STPSourceReceiver.html#/c:objc(c.abstract: The total amount that was returned to the customer.

Classes/STPSourceParams.html#/c:objc(cs).name: type
Classes/STPSourceParams.html#/c:objc(cs).abstract: The type of the source to create. Required.

Classes/STPSourceParams.html#/c:objc(cs).name: rawTypeString

It renders as a spinning circle with a gap in it, similar to what you see in the App Store app or in the Apple Pay dialog when making a purchase. To change its color, set the tintColor property.

Classes/STPPaymentCardTextField.html.name: STPPaymentCardTextField
Classes/STPPaymentCardTextField.html.abstract: STPPaymentCardTextField is a text field with similar properties to UITextField, but specialized for collecting credit/debit card information. It manages multiple UITextFields under the hood to collect this information. It’s designed to fit on a single line, and from a design perspective can be used anywhere a UITextField would be appropriate.

Classes/STPPaymentContext.html.name: STPPaymentContext
Classes/STPPaymentContext.html.abstract: An STPPaymentContext keeps track of all of the state around a payment. It will manage fetching a user’s saved payment methods, tracking any information they select, and prompting them for required additional information before completing their purchase. It can be used to power your application’s payment confirmation page with just a few lines of code.

Classes/STPPaymentMethodsViewController..name: STPPaymentMethodsViewController
Classes/STPPaymentMethodsViewController..abstract: This view controller presents a list of payment method options to the user, which they can select between. They can also add credit cards to the list. It must be displayed inside a UINavigationController, so you can either create a UINavigationController with an STPPaymentMethodsViewController as the rootViewController and then present the UINavigationController, or push a new STPPaymentMethodsViewController onto an existing UINavigationController‘s stack. You can also have STPPaymentContext do this for you automatically, by calling presentPaymentMethodsViewController or pushPaymentMethodsViewController on it.

Classes/STPPaymentResult.html.name: STPPaymentResult
Classes/STPPaymentResult.html.abstract: When you’re using STPPaymentContext to request your user’s payment details, this is the object that will be returned to your application when they’ve successfully made a payment. It currently just contains a source, but in the future will include any relevant metadata as well. You should pass source.stripeID to your server, and call the charge creation endpoint. This assumes you are charging a Customer, so you should specify the customer parameter to be that customer’s ID and the source parameter to the value returned here. For more information, see https://stripe.com/docs/api#create_charge

Depending on your configuration’s shippingType, the view controller may present a shipping method selection form after the user enters an address.
